Comment: When n = -1 follow the integration rules for  $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$

Formula:
$ {\Large\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) dx \approx \dfrac{b-a} {2n} {\Large\{} f(a) + f(b) + 2 {\Large[} f(x_1)+...+f(x_{n-1}){\Large ]} {\Large\}}$
$ \text { where } a=x_0 \text{ and } b=x_n $

Comment: ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation.
Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value?

Formula:
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }  = cos^{-1}f(x) + c \text{ or } -sin^{-1}f(x) +c$
$ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $

$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }  = cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c \text{ or } -sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$
$ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $

Comment: Formula can be utilised to calculate otherwise hard to differentiate inverse functions

Formula:
$ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $
$ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of }  \dfrac{n+1}{2} $

$\text{An outlier is a score with} $
$ \text {   less than } Q1 - 1.5  \times IQR $
$ \text {   or more than than } Q3 + 1.5  \times IQR $
